title: Travel briefs
text:
Columbus, Ohio • Aug 09, 2015 • 67° Scattered Clouds The Columbus Dispatch Need help? Visit our FAQ page or use our Contact Form . Customer Service Need help? For retail advertising, call 614-461-5500 or email us . For national advertising, call 614-461-5199. For online advertising, call 614-461-5143 or email us . Newsroom Use our Contact Form , or call 614-461-5200. Dispatch Careers Visit dispatch.com/careers or call 614-461-5033. Fax 614-461-5565. Sunday August 9, 2015 5:00 AM Museum sets Aviation Day 
What better place to celebrate Orville Wright’s birthday (Aug. 19) — also National Aviation Day — than the National Museum of the United States Air Force? 
On Saturday, the Air Force museum near Dayton will offer special Aviation Day activities as part of a Family Day celebration featuring demonstrations and hands-on activities. The free event will run from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. 
For information, call 937-255-3286 or visit www.nationalmuseum.af.mil 
Nelsonville plans 4-day fest 
Downtown Nelsonville will host the Parade of the Hills festival from Wednesday through Saturday. 
Live entertainment including fiddle music, races for adults and children, games and rides are planned in Nelsonville Public Square during the free event. 
Call 740-753-3525 or visit www.paradeofthehills.org 
Bratwursts to be devoured 
The Bucyrus Bratwurst Festival will be held in the Ohio city’s downtown from Thursday through Saturday. 
The free event includes parades, the Best “Wurst” Bike Tour, contests, a crafts show, an arts show and a pageant. 
Call 1-866-562-0720 or visit www.bucyrus.org 
Lake Erie isle offers bash 
Kelleys Island will hold its annual homecoming festival from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday. 
The free event will offer entertainment, nature exhibits, games, contests and a creative-costume parade. 
Call 419-746-2432 or visit www.kelleysislandlandowners.org or kelleysislandchamber.com 
Detroit park added to list 
Detroit’s Lafayette Park, a successful urban renewal project near the city’s downtown, has been named a national historic landmark. 
The National Park Service announced last week that the neighborhood, redeveloped in the mid-20th century featuring the architecture of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, and three other sites nationwide have been added to the list of historic landmarks. 
Lafayette Park is a racially and ethnically diverse neighborhood consisting of town houses, two high-rises and a shopping center that is next to a park of the same name. 
More than 2,500 sites are on the list of national historic landmarks. The park service typically adds five to 10 sites annually. 
— From staff and wire reports
